content.description: Start the Northeast arete from the large shelf jug.  Head left as for that route.

Climb from a low start into the northeast arete, trending back to the east face along the diagonal.  Topout off the deck.  

 From the starting jug/lip-crimp, make move on crimps to reach the incredible shelf/jug.  Move left along the diagonal on the east face.
content.protection: 3 pads is ideal, one of them being a large pad.
content.location: At the bottom of the east face (overhanging), is a beautiful curved jug.  Start left hand, left heel here.  Right hand on a crimp on the lip (of the bottom of the boulder) of the north face.

content.description:
Starting the same as A Colorful Little Orgy on a left crescent jug low on the east face and right on an undercling pinch brick just under the roof adjacent to the jug, make the same hard sequence into the crimps on the lip of the north face arete and climb upwards into the jug shelf. From here, bust right onto the north face through a bizarre V6 or 7 face climb involving tenuous, delicate and extremely reachy movement on poor-to-non-holds with decent feet to the positive lip above an undercling arch feature. 

 Highly morpho and will feel easier with good conditions–the FA was done late night by floodlights for the best temperatures.
content.protection: Sloping landing and insecure climbing means the more pads the better. Small cams and cord or slings are very useful to mitigate pad sliding.
content.location: Same start as A Colorful Little Orgy, but exits right onto and up through the blankest section of the north face after gaining the jug shelf where the NE Arete Stand begins.

content.description: From the high center rail on the east face, make a big move out right to the diagonal rail.  Follow this feature to topout the same as the Northeast Arete.
content.location: Start from a stand on the high center rail on the East face.

content.description:
Start left hand on obvious crescent jug at the bottom of the east face and right on an undercling pinch just under the roof below the jug. Make a hard move(s) (long arms helpful) into a crimp on the arete on lip of the north face and finish on "Northeast Arete Sit". 

 AKA the Jake Croft Memorial Boulder Problem and formerly The Summit Project. Found and tried by Raines, then handed off to Jake, who tried it extensively before moving to Sweden and handing it off to me. Psyched to finish the duo's hard work on this one in a night sesh with our homie Jefe.
content.protection: Three or more pads. The V2+ topout is less secure than it may seem and backslaps are likely while working the crux first sequence into the right hand start for NE Arete SDS. The landing slopes away, so a few small cams and cord/slings to fix the pads onto the slab are helpful.
content.location: Starts laying down below the roof on the downhill side of the Quartzite Spring boulder. Starts left on a crescent jug just above the lip of the roof on the east face and an undercling pinch brick just below the roof adjacent to the jug. The left is the same start hold as for NE Arete SDS.

content.description:
A beautiful sheer overhanging face, visible from the piped Quartzite spring. This boulder looks small from the trail, but will look intimidatingly tall when your standing under it, as the landing slopes away.

 I highly recommend bringing singles BD 0.3-0.5 or equivalent and two sections of ~8ft cord to fix your pads, as some of the landing is on angling slab.
